My bill would repeal this 25% cap, and call on @POTUS to advocate for needed reforms at the UN. This is a quick policy fix that would have a huge impact on U.S. credibility, the financial health of the UN, and advancement of important reform.

In 2018, China and Russia successfully lobbied for the Human Rights Upfront Initiative to be disbanded. This was an important initiative to the U.S. that strengthened and prioritized human rights in UN engagements.

These dues have also diminished our standing at the UN. It creates a leadership vacuum and undermines our ability to push for accountability and reform efforts – including human rights initiatives – at the UN.

Many developing nations that provide the bulk of peacekeeping troops aren't fully reimbursed for their contributions. These shortfalls amount to tens of millions of dollars each for developing nations like Bangladesh, Ghana, and Tanzania.

Did you know that Congress established a 25% cap on contributions to #UNPeacekeeping in 1994? Our actual share of funding that we have agreed to at the UN is a little over 27%, meaning we are constantly in debt to the UN. The impact?
This week, I introduced the U.S. Commitment to Peacekeeping Act, a bill to make sure the United States fulfills our commitments to the United Nations.
